reviews.comment_content:
I would say it is too much but it's the fact that you cannot avoid.  Every lecture is averaging 100 slides. Therefore, get prepared.

Also, i would say that the lectures taught by Karl are quite a lot more difficult than Jessica's. They require much much more understanding than the topics Jessica teaches. Especially the development part. Therefore, again, get prepared.

Although there is too much content, you'll need that.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Both professors are really really good. Both will listen to us carefully and patiently answer our questions after class.

Also, they both are caring professors. For example, Karl intentionally said he will allow Christian students to not attend lectures about evolution if they fell uncomfortable about what he said and he will provide help to them and try to adjust the marks.
reviews.comment_grading:
I think it is quite good. I was 0.5 SD above mean in mid-term. They did not release the score in final and i got A finally.

Therefore....I don't know! ^^''
reviews.comment_workload:
No homework. Just testing your limit of memory even if you study the notes regularly. (You still need short memory)

So, good luck!

reviews.author: diudiu
reviews.title: 資訊量大但係唔難
reviews.comment_content:
Two halves, first half (Herrup) centers around DNA, evolution, reproduction, and genetics, topics which are examined in midterm. The second half (Tang) is mostly about human physiology, with two lectures of biotechnology and application closing the course.

Herrup loves to add a lot of extra details in his half, and some might find themselves in severe information overload, if you
(a) are not very good at language esp. listening
(b) do not possess a good foundation of biology
(c) are too lazy to look up his bonus materials
Herrup's part, however, is easily, hands down, the funnest section in the course.

Tang's half is about the different systems in humans. Not much to learn here, and the lectures are perfectly skippable. Not that you could 吃中學老本, but the workload here is near zero compared to Herrup's part.
reviews.comment_teaching:
I intended to give an A here because of Prof Herrup but a C for Dr Tang, so here it is, a B.
Many would say Professor Herrup speaks way too fast and covers too many complex course contents, but seriously I think this is just the way native speakers teach. It is simply natural for the professor to try and share as much as his knowledge to students.
Dr. Tang, meanwhile, is a typical Hong Kong lecturer. She speaks with a pretty Hongkong-ish accent you might find......rather.......hypnotizzzing. Well in her defense she got the way less interesting part, i.e. human physiology, a topic largely overlapping with DSE biology.
reviews.comment_grading:
A very intriguing system was used in the examinations. Along with the multiple choice questions (60 for midterm, 100 for final), there were "multiple answer multiple choice" questions with some 7 to 10 choices from which you have to choose up to 5 correct options. These questions make up 20 marks in each exam.

Not sure about the grading since it was kind of irrelevant to me, but here are some stats.
76.4% midterm, >2.4 SD, mean 49.6%, max 84%
87.2% final, mean 54.8% iirc
--> A+.
reviews.comment_workload:
Huh what can I say here? No assignments, no readings, non-cumulative exams, the workload here was very low.
To be honest I only revised for
3 days for midterm
23 hours for final
from scratch and still turned out fine

Well unless you intend on self-churring by actually reading the papers included in Herrup's powerpoints I suppose. lel

reviews.author: iamthrookeed
reviews.comment_content:
In-depth teaching for materials that mostly have been covered in high school (genetics, DNA, evolution, development and ageing, biotechnology, and organ systems: reproduction, nervous system, lymphatic & immune system, circulatory system, respiratory system, digestive system, excretory system)
The content is from Inquiry into Life textbook by Sylvia S. Mader, 14th ed. You might consider buying it if you want to read the additional material from the book, but it's not really important. The questions for self-practice is quite helpful in familiarising you with the questions in the midterm and final, although I'd say it was not really similar and sufficient.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Herrup is good but Dr. Tang is not. The lecture videos are available so you don't need to attend the lectures. Dr. Tang only reads from her slides anyway.
reviews.comment_grading: I think you need to get at least 0.5SD (or 0.6SD/0.7SD) above mean for the midterm and cram for the final for 1 week (it's relative, depends on how efficient you are) to get A range, but you should really put a big effort on your final.
reviews.comment_workload: No reading is required, just need to memorise a lot of things. No assignment. No attendance for lectures.

reviews.author: USTian
reviews.comment_content:
The course covered topics mainly on DNA, genetics and human biology. If you are interested in human biology and disease, this course will be quite enjoyable.

1. DNA Structure (Ch. 25), Control of Gene Expression
2. Human Genetics - Genes & Chromosomes (Ch. 23~24)
3. Reproduction (Ch. 21)
4. Evolution (Ch. 27)
5. Endocrine System (Ch. 20)
6. Development & Aging (Ch. 22)
7. Nervous System (Ch. 17)
8. Lymphatic & Immune Systems (Ch. 13), Infectious Diseases
9. Circulatory System (Ch. 12)
10. Respiratory System (Ch. 15)
11. Processing & Nutrition - Digestive System (Ch. 14)
12. Osmoregulation & Excretion - Excretory system (Ch. 16)
12. Biotechnology (Ch. 26)

* Chapter numbers based on textbook chapters of <Inquiry into Life> by Sylvia S. Mader, 14th ed..
reviews.comment_teaching: I went to Prof. Herrup's lectures, but barely went to Prof. Tang's. Both professors did post videos of the lectures, so you could watch them, or just read the PPTs and the suggested textbook.
reviews.comment_grading:
Midterm Exam - 40%
Final Exam - 60%

The exams are noncumulative, fortunately.
I got 1.2 SD above mean (mean = 49.6%) for the midterm, and didn't have time to go over 2 chapters for the final, but still received an A.
reviews.comment_workload: There are no assignments or compulsory readings since only the exams count for marks. I did read the suggested textbook <Inquiry into Life> by Sylvia S. Mader, and found it quite helpful. But if you don't seem to have enough time to go through the textbook, don't, because it does have a lot of unimportant information too. Try out the textbook questions though, because one of them that I just skimmed through actually appeared on the final exam.

reviews.author: Eugenecsk
reviews.comment_content:
Herrup 教授的內容會比較艱深。聽高年級同學表示有一些課題其實在之後2000,3000 Lvl才會教,esp 是DNA and Protein Synthesis 那一部份。
Jessica 負責課題內容一大部份涵蓋DSE Biology。
reviews.comment_teaching:
Herrup幽默感不錯，上課比較生動，會偶爾有一點笑話。講課也不盡是Read Slideshow。
反之Jessica上課和Read Slideshow 沒有分別。accent 令人聽得很辛苦。
reviews.comment_grading:
一般。
Mid term 大概mean, final above mean ~1.5 SD，最後A range。
其他同學Mid term 和final mean左右也有B Range。
reviews.comment_workload: 沒有功課。上課不Take Attendance。考試全MC。只是要背的有點多。

reviews.author: kentanggoreng
reviews.comment_content: Everything is about basic biology, which most people already get from highschool. Not demanding at all.
reviews.comment_teaching: Jessica was a pain to listen to. She talks in a very robotic fashion, and often only reads from the presentation she prepared beforehand. You will not last 90 minutes listening to her. Randy was much better, he was interesting and engaging to the students.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading was decent and reasonable to the amount of studying and effort you put into the course.
reviews.comment_workload: Just studying for the exams and nothing else. Reading the book can give you beneficial extra knowledge for the exams.

reviews.author: Asflsy
reviews.comment_content:
Mainly focused on systems in human body, respiratory system, nervous system,  digestive system, etc,etc. Some other parts (like DNA, evolution) are also talked about in several chapters.
Totally 24 chapters. Knowledge taught is very rich and detailed.
The most difficult part is the vocabulary for many nonnative English speakers like me.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Karl is humorous and responsible. He can somehow explain those complicated concepts very clear.
Jessica is not so organized as Karl but still good and clear.
reviews.comment_grading: To be fair, the grading is okay. I got both my exams below mean and a B-. It should be easy for many.
reviews.comment_workload:
We need to handle both the knowledge and the vocab.
10 hours a week might not be enough.

reviews.author: kk
reviews.comment_content:
Before mid-term: circulatory system, digestive system, lymphatic system, urinary system and respiratory system
After mid-term: endocrine, nervous system, reproduction, gene inheritance, development and aging, chromosomal inheritance and biotechnology
The content after mid-term is much more than that before mid-term. There are over 1000 slides in total.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Some videos will be played during the class to strengthen your understanding.
PRS during the class is used to check your understanding about the topic.
Prof Wong's explanation for the content is more detailed. Jessica sometimes just follows the ppt to read.
reviews.comment_grading:
Fair grade
Effort and grade are directly proportional to each other.
Biology lovers may get better grade.
reviews.comment_workload:
50% mid-term
50% final
No hw, prs is not for grading
but there are quite a lot of content that you need to study

reviews.author: 小龜
reviews.title: 付出和收入成正比
reviews.comment_content: 這課主要教人體的各個system，算是很標準的life science入門course。難度比DSE bio深入不少，所以不要想著吃老本。當然，DSE讀過還是很大優勢的。
reviews.comment_teaching:
我那年是Prof。 Wong教上半截，Jessica 教下半截。

Prof Wong的教學我自己很喜歡。他很喜歡把問題作深入擴展，做邏輯推斷。他出的mid term 雖然是純mc（太好了，沒有學過拉丁文的我最討厭背名詞），但有些題目真的要求你能把學到的內容理解然後串聯起來，很有意思。

Jessica 的教法就是照ppt讀。作為不是對bio特別感興趣鑽研的phys人來說感覺就是她不斷用你不明的theory/term去解釋你不明白的theory/term...（利申：DSE英文考bio)。出席率嘛，明顯比Prof Wong 教的時候低。上課隨時準備查wiki，會有幫助的。
reviews.comment_grading:
Grade來說我覺得是可以的。
mid term比max差一分
final 高一個sd最後拿A。
我有個朋友midterm差我一點final好我一點就 A+了。

這個course最好的地方就是你基本花了時間去讀基本就可以甩mean一條街。
reviews.comment_workload:
沒有Assignment,只有mid term 和 final。
但是，這不代表沒有workload。每一課過百頁ppt，每一個caption都是重點，所以要考好基本有讀海量內容的準備....

YH Wong的內容比較容易在堂上理解，所以準備不是需要特別多；Jessica那截...我基本上課沒有什麼能記起來的，以致我在final前溫了兩個星期，把教科書完整看了遍，才把邏輯理清楚了...

引用一句來自 msssug 一篇review的一句話：
輕鬆一時爽，grade就火葬場。

reviews.author: royalmilktea
reviews.comment_content:
(see course outline for list of topics)
A lot of it was high school biology on steroids
There are probably a lot more details in there though that you'll need to know for the exams.
I guess the course is useful if you want to put biology in a context that is relatable to humans and to daily life (versus other more molecular/cellular level courses later in the LIFS program)

Reading the textbook is helpful but is not a must if you want a good grade (since things are pretty much all taught in class / in lecture notes anyway)

LIFS 1902 is pretty much a make-or-break course. After you take it you'll either feel like biology is your calling (if you like memorization and you see how useful studying biology is) or it's the grossest thing you'll ever study (especially for people who hate memorization). So if you want to know whether studying life science is for you, I'd suggest checking this course out.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Jessica is a pretty normal local lecturer
teaches to the notes, kind of reads from it...
I'd suggest you get a cup of coffee before class if you get bored easily
But if you're interested in finding out more you can always ask her after class, she's very nice about talking to students and answering questions.

Professor Poon is pretty... stylistic. You'll hear him talking about history, the arts... etc (and no they won't appear in the final so don't worry about memorizing old abortion drug names)
His teaching is decently interesting, and you'll definitely live without the coffee.
I just feel like he's not very approachable when it comes to questions after class. People say he treats girls nicer though(?)
reviews.comment_grading: Give yourself at least one week before the exam to study. You'll need that time to memorize all these things. And then you'll do fine.
reviews.comment_workload:
No homework at all (which is very nice)
But a lot of things to study for the midterm and final.
Good luck.

reviews.author: Research+Doc
reviews.title: Great course for human biology and disease science lovers
reviews.comment_content:
To those who are looking for biochemical pathways and cellular details -- abandon all hope. This course is really about human biology, diseases, and the central dogma (DNA, mRNA and protein -- you know it).

The anatomy part requires some good language sense, and memorization is of course inevitable. Diseases are incredibly fun and not as difficult to study as you might imagine. The developmental biology, though, requires extensive Wikipedia reading and emailing Prof Herrup. It's extremely time-consuming, but the joy from understanding these processes makes it worthwhile.

To be fair though, people who are gonna work at research labs for UROP will probably find this course mostly, if not completely, useless. It's not very helpful for biochemistry courses later on too I guess. So unless you wanna transfer to medical schools (for which this course is near-perfect), just think of the contents as something good to know, and no pressure really.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Jessica's extremely nice, but reads of the powerpoints in a slightly sleep-inducing manner, albeit with very clear English. She's pretty helpful if you ask her questions personally, and typically replies to emails within 12 hours.

Prof Herrup is as nice as Jessica, but possesses the aura of a great scientist who isn't afraid of saying 'I don't know', and provides very inspiring, insightful and adequately exam-friendly answers. His lectures are fantastically delivered in a fun, interactive and clear manner. The only thing you'd grunt about him is that he takes quite a few days, if not week(s), to reply, and that's given that he decides to reply. Super professor overall, personal favourite.
reviews.comment_grading: Very lenient, I must say.
reviews.comment_workload: Very, very light. No assignment, just midterm and final (all MC!!!!). Usually you'll have around 30-45 minutes left in the exams so plenty of time for checking and thinking.

reviews.author: 孤獨的美食家
reviews.title: For Biology lovers
reviews.comment_content:
Difficulty of the course depends on how you study Biology and are you a Bio-lover or not. Mainly focus on Physiology and Simple genetics.
A lot of stuff to remember. As you know, this is a Bio courses, bunches of terms are needed to be remembered.
As I know there are over 20 diseases and 20 hormones.
If you are not interested in Biology, this course will be hard for you
reviews.comment_teaching:
Biology is hard to be funny at all, and the content makes the teaching boring.
Wong's deliver skills is acceptable. But the content still make you fall asleep.
Jessica is even boring than Wong, like a high school teacher. But her reply speeds for the Emails are really fast. I tried to write a mail to her just after the lesson, and I received the reply at the evening.
reviews.comment_grading:
Seems to be fair. Knowing that the grading is different from Fall-sem.
Heard from my friend that around the mean for both Midterm and Final, he finally got a B-.
But I got the highest score in both Midterm and Final, so I cant give much comments on it.
reviews.comment_workload: Only MT and Final, not the others. But it will make you stay in hell during the revision period.

reviews.author: moonn
reviews.title: need to be very hard-working
reviews.comment_content:
The content is related to the textbook Inquiry into Life, 16 or 17 version.
Course Introduction and Nervous system (17)
Musculoskeletal System (19)
Heart and the Circulatory system (12)
Respiratory system (15)
Osmoregulation and Excretion (16)(actually not included)--Miller
DNA structure and gene expression (25)
Patterns of gene inheritance (23)
Chromosomal basis of inheritance (24)
Biotechnology (26)--Liang
Digestive System and Nutrition (14)
Endocrine System (20)
Lymphatic and Immune Systems (13)
Development and Aging (22)--Li
As a mainland student, I found it very different from what I learned from high school. So with so many words to remember, it is quite hard to take this class.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Miller's class is very fun. He tried to connect biology knowledge with daily life to make it easier to understand. However his slides is very long and it is hard to review the knowledge to prepare the exam according the slides. And I think his slides has little to do with the textbook.
Professor LIang's class is also good. His class is much deeper and he focus more on students' thinking. You need to do a lot of homework after class to totally understand what he wants to say. The content of his class is most hard and deepest, but it is not a bad thing. After all it is most related to what I learned in high school  compared to other two teachers.
Dr.Li's slides are most clear, and it is much easier to review according to her slides. The content is also OK. But she almost just follows her slides and reads them.
reviews.comment_grading:
Midterm 75MCs 80mins    55/75 B+
Final exam 75MCs 100mins   unknown
But I got A in total eventually.
The midterm I didn't care about so much. The time is quite short and I almost didn't finish all the questions. But the most surprised me is Professor Miller's questions. I must WARN that, ALL HIS SLIDES could be the questions. Foe example, one question is about the Freud's dream theory, and the other is about who got the Nobel Prize in that year.
So the final exam I prepared so hard. I spent 4 hours per day to review and the grade is actually beyond my thought.
reviews.comment_workload: No homework so it could be quite relaxing. But if you want to get a good grade, you must work very hard.

reviews.author: mading18
reviews.title: Actually a human physiology course
reviews.comment_content:
Miller:
- Nervous system(which is a psychology lecture in disguise)
- Musculoskeletal
- Heart and Circulation
- Lungs and Respiration
- Osmoregulation and Excretion(Miller didn't get to this lecture in time so he removed this section in the midterms)
Liang:
- DNA, gene expression(Transcription/Translation), cancer
- Patterns of genetic inheritance
(THIS IS WHERE MIDTERMS OCCURRED)
- Chromosomal Basis of Inheritance
- Biotechnology
Li:
- Digestive System
- Endocrine System/Hormonal control
- Lympathic/Immune System
- Development and Aging

Midterms cover all content up to patterns of gene inheritance, finals cover content from chromosomal basis of inheritance to end
Basic biology content that goes deeper into the known concepts with more detail.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The 3 professors each have drastically different teaching styles.
Miller is very kind and entertaining. He explains the content clearly(well the content he teaches is generally easy to begin with) and frequently asks the class to revise/recall what he said during the lecture.
One thing to note about Miller: He really likes the details in his lectures. While his powerpoints may appear simple enough, every small detail(like the names of the two layers of connective muscle tissue and the formula for blood flow) will very likely end up on the exam. If Miller is teaching first, the very first lecture you will have in LIFS1902 will be something about psychoanalysis and psychology. Most people will think this content is useless and not pay attention in class. In fact, he WILL test you on stuff related to psychology, and it accounts for a sizeable portion of the exam questions(around 10-15). Even frivolous questions like who Konrad Lorenz or Simone de Beauvoir are will be asked. So make sure to memorize EVERYTHING from his powerpoints.

Liang sure likes conceptual understanding and logical reasoning. He would frequently stop lectures to ask about why something occurs or why something is this and not that, then answers the question himself using logic. This will help you understand the concepts better but could get confusing at times.
Liang teaches the "nitty gritty" content of this course. His DNA and gene expression lecture(related to replication, transcription and translation, and cell control) is by far the hardest LIFS1902 lecture (to understand) you will experience and the questions asked by him in this module are the most difficult(I probably got many of those questions wrong).

Li's teaching is a bit more "generic" than Liang's and Miller's. Apparently she's much newer to teaching this course; I still think her teaching's fine, just not as "engaging" as Miller or Liang. She allows students to directly ask questions on Canvas mid-lecture and answers these questions in-class, which could be helpful in conceptual understanding.  By the way, unlike Miller, you do not have to remember every detail she puts in her powerpoints; it's impossible if you do. The content she teaches is generally easier than Liang's but still covers a lot of new content not necessarily covered in high school biology. The questions she asks in the final exam are also easier than Liang's, although it would only be easy if you fully memorized all the important details in her lecture.

In my opinion(all 3 are good instructors though):
Nature of content(how easy is it to understand and remember): Miller > Li > Liang (except for that weird psychology lecture Miller gave)
Teaching quality: Miller > Liang > Li
Difficulty of content: Liang > Miller = Li
reviews.comment_grading:
Having no quizzes and assignments comes with its own curse: the exams. They're not "hard", it's just they can only grade you on the exams.
Basically 50% midterms, 50% finals
Midterms was 75 MCQ's and that's it
Finals was also 75 MCQ's and that's it
So your entire grade relies on 150 multiple choice questions. In my opinion, that's not good.
You would find this very aggravating especially if you tend to get nervous or mess up during examinations because there is no other way to redeem your score if you do poorly in exams. But I guess most LIFS lecture courses are like that due to how many people take them, smh...

For me:
Midterms: 89.33% (67/75)
Finals: Unknown
Grade: A+
reviews.comment_workload:
No assignments, no quizzes, no homework, no projects.
Many people are attracted to this course because of this promise(or, of course, they're choosing LIFS major and have this pre-enrolled).
You may start off this class thinking that it's very easy because there are no assignments or quizzes or anything.

WRONG.

If you decide to revise frequently(which is what you should do in this course if you want good grades), this course quickly becomes one of the most demanding courses in your schedule.
Start revising at least 3 weeks before exams. Go through and re-write your notes, use the textbook to your advantage(if you bought it, if not that's still okay), watch the extra videos for Liang's content while making sure you understand his main concepts, re-watch Li's lectures if you're confused about some of the content, and photocopy all of Miller's taught lecture powerpoints into your brain(this works because Miller will give questions about content found exclusively in his powerpoints and nothing else). Your hard work will be rewarded with an excellent grade.

reviews.author: WhyTee
reviews.title: Decent couse, content is not always logically structured
reviews.comment_content:
Content and emphasis on certain topics strongly depend on the professor.
Prof Miller is sometimes going into too much details (I enjoyed these details, others may not) and usually skip a lot of content that can be usually considered classical in the context of biology course (In nervous system lectures you may expect neurons and structure of CNS, but he focuses on psychology, psychoanalysis, and disorders).
Prof Liang is trying to build scientific reasoning skills and usually introduces interesting discussion questions. Also, some specific topics are very detailed, others were kind of overlooked.
Prof Li is giving way more broad and foundational knowledge, covering important topics not very deep but in a detailed way. Most logical design of lectures.
reviews.comment_teaching: Teaching is on a decent level, if you attend lectures it is easy to understand each topic, amount of information could seem exhausting, however as long as you keep up with the material and actively think about lectures, there are not problems with memorizing information.
reviews.comment_grading: Curved grading, regular distribution of marks (about 20% get A range). Exams require you to be familiar with specific facts (Miller and Li parts), questions from Liang may seem little bit more tricky for students.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is very light, with only 2 lectures per week.
You need to dedicate some time to reviewing course materials before the midterm and final.

reviews.author: NRG803
reviews.comment_content: Some basic Biology stuff, you have learnt most of them in high school already.
reviews.comment_teaching: Didn’t really attend any lesson, so sorry couldn’t help.
reviews.comment_grading:
I think grading consists of
1. Final exam
2. Online quiz
3. Essay
4. Class participation

The marking transparency is very low, the only results I received is my online quiz, which I score slightly below mean every time.

I think I have a zero as class participation, but do remember that if you miss tutorial more than 3 times your grade would be deducted(as the professor claims).

I don’t know how well did I perform in my finals and the essays, but I got a A-, so I ain’t complaining.
reviews.comment_workload: I would say alright. No midterm tho so that’s a saving grace

reviews.author: Anthropologist
reviews.title: A course highly relied on memorize
reviews.comment_content: this course covered some basic information in a wide range of topics in biology, including cell division,  embryonic development, digestive system, respiratory system, reproductive system, nervous system, urinary system and something related to basic nutrition and so on.
reviews.comment_teaching: all of the three teachers are very responsible and will to answer any of your questions at any time. the classes are conducted in a relaxed and pleasant atmosphere. They are all very humorous and very kind to students.
reviews.comment_grading:
Not good.
you need to get a grade above mean by 1SD to get A+.
It can be very hard.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is very heavy especially if you are not from English speaking country because you have to memorize a large amount of specified words.

reviews.author: Grasswall
reviews.comment_content:
Extreme amount of content in lectures. Content is basic but in vast amount.
Memorization is the only requirement in this course.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Liang and Lam has the most prepared lectures and teaches in adequate speed. Professor Herrup however drags the lectures out on explaining simple content making it slightly redundant. All 3 is able to show their passion on their field of research and encourages question.
reviews.comment_grading: Normal lifs grade
reviews.comment_workload: A lot of study materials for both midterm and final. There are only 1 mid term and 1 final making this course less restricting.

reviews.author: Andy HK
reviews.comment_content:
Contain some secondary school knowledge.
Topics include internal transport, lymphatic,immune system and infectious diseases, processing food and nutrition, gas exchange, osmoregulation and excretion, nervous system, endocrine regulation, reproduction, development and aging, human genetics-chromosomal basis of inheritance and patterns of gene inheritance and finally biotechnology.
The lecture notes of dr. tang are not well-organised enough and are very messy.
Nervous system is quite difficult.
There are plenty of terms to memorize and it is very very very crazy.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Boring and not useful. Many students prefer self-study instead of attending class. The pace of teaching is very fast so the concepts are not clearly explained.
There will be some online exercises on canvas to help you study and clear some of your concepts which are quite important so you should do all of them, But the exercises would not count for any marks.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading is not very good. I only got a B grade even if i got 7x% in total.
reviews.comment_workload: It only has mid term and final exam and has no assignments,essays or projects.

reviews.author: chloew
reviews.title: LIFS 1902
reviews.comment_content:
DNA structure and gene expression
Patterns of gene inheritance
Chromosomal basis of inheritance
Development
Reproduction
Endocrine system
Evolution
Aging
Circulatory system

Mid-term exam

Respiratory system
Lymphatic, immune systems & infectious diseases
Osmoregulation & excretion

Biotechnology

Basically a slightly more detailed version of the DSE syllabus.
Perfect transition from DSE to uni, which is great.
Gives a board understanding human biology in general.
reviews.comment_teaching:
HERRUP, Karl
LIANG, Chun
LAM, Philip

Teaching is great.
All three professors are very passionate in what they teach, and teaching itself.

Liang tries to include a lot of extra resources to help students understand more of the material. Provides a lot o online materials as well. He tries to thrown in a few jokes as well to make lectures more fun as well. They way he talks could be a little boring, but overall it was great.

Lam really tries to make students feel as comfortable as possible. He makes sure students understand what he wants to deliver to students. He sometimes include iPRS questions as well. His lectures are fun and lively and easy to follow. He plays music when its break time which is so refreshing and fun and relaxing.

Herrup is amazing. He includes a lot of humor in his lectures to make lectures more fun. He throws in a lot of analogy to make students understand the material more easily. He is interactive with the class. He checks on how students are doing before class whenever its close to an exam period. He keeps messing up with the projector tho, that's a bit annoying but I am sure it is annoying for him as well so -

They all give good ppts, although i personally prefer Lam's and Herrup's a bit more.

All lectures were videotaped and put to Canvas.

Having different lecturers or different chapters is not the funest thing ever.
reviews.comment_grading:
Midterm 50% Final 50%
All MCQs,
some multiple choice questions, however, have 7-10 choices with multiple answers.
Basic understanding of the subject will not do it, you will have to make sure you know the exact little details.
reviews.comment_workload:
No assignments.
Since the materials are not difficult at all, just read your ppts before and after lectures and you will be fine.

reviews.author: Minerva
reviews.comment_content:
- Internal transport
- Lymphatic, immune system & infectious diseases
- Processing food & nutrition
- Gas exchange
- Osmoregulation & excretion
- Nervous system
- Endocrine regulation

- Development & aging

All these are good to know, but they are too much. I think they need to be split into two separate classes.
reviews.comment_teaching: Boring. Super boring.
reviews.comment_grading:
Midterm (35%)
Final (65%)

I got around 1 sd above for the midterm. (mean: 63.5, sd: 13.05)
The final exam result was not released, but I think I did pretty well.
My final grade was A+.
reviews.comment_workload: Even though there are no assignments, workload is extremely high due to the amount of contents. You need to spend a massive amount of time to understand and memorize every single part of our body for the exams. Good luck!

reviews.author: Pinkylaucp
reviews.comment_content:
lots of ppt slides to memorize
Herrup speaked too fast, so i had to read through the textbook to catch up with the content, otherwise you have to ask him after class to clarify the contents
reviews.comment_teaching: Their teaching is very clear and can be easily understood, though Herrup sometimes speaked too fast
reviews.comment_grading:
excellent grading
most of my friends got A range for the course
if you are willing to study, then you can get A range easily
reviews.comment_workload:
mid term and final exam only, no attendence taken
final exam is not acumulative
exams are MCQ only

reviews.author: Minerva07
reviews.comment_content:
the former part of the course is about DNA structure and expression, basic genetics, some of evolution.
after midterm, the course is mainly about the eight systems of human.
reviews.comment_teaching:
professor Herrup is very good at teaching and often interact with students. he is usually very nice and funny, giving vivid explanations. But there are times when students did not take the class seriously, talk very loudly in class, or play with the display screen... so the professor may get mad a little. his ppt is too abstract, without much information, so you need to attend the lectures.
professor Liang's class has a lot of information and the speed is relatively faster. however, the class is a little bit boring. the ppt is good.
reviews.comment_grading:
fair grading.
the exam is all multiple choices questions. most are single answer questions, a few multiple answers questions.
reviews.comment_workload: almost no workload, only one midterm, and one final exam. the professor did not take attendance at all. so if you like, you can read ppt before the exams and not go to lectures. no assignments either.

reviews.author: Hahaha
reviews.comment_content: Learnt high school level biology. In the sense, AP BIology/IB Biology High level. For each lecture, we finished half of the ppt on average ( 50 pages out of 100 pages). We went over human physiology in detail. Starting from Basic genetics, we learnt Digestion, Respiration and breathing, circulation, hormones, evolution, excretion, sexual reproduction, and  etc.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Karl's lecture was interesting. He took quiz for almost all the lectures and made sure we knew what we were learning. He taught the first half of the lectures and the rest by Jessica.
reviews.comment_grading: Prof. Karl's grading system is very strict and the way he gives exam is very tricky. However, If you know all the concepts in the ppt properly, You are safe to get A range.
reviews.comment_workload: It may depend from person to person, but I think it is easy to manage if you don't procrastinate studying for the whole semester.

reviews.comment_teaching:
Herrup and Liang both are passionate about teaching. If you ask them questions , they will definitely ans you.
Herrup is a intersting professor who is really good at teaching!Never got bored in class.
reviews.comment_grading:
I got B and my midterm and final results are a little bit above mean.
50%midterm and 50%final.
No additional homework.
reviews.comment_workload: Most of the content is relative to the course and at an appropriate level. If you study well for the exam and go to lecture/watch lecture video it should be fine.

reviews.author: Fickdeinemutter
reviews.comment_content:
我係以前冇讀過Bio嘅人，讀完LIFS 1901再讀呢個，的確係幾深，腸胃胸肺呢啲都還單背就掂，但最深嗰課都係腎，係難到唔係人咁品……

背好多野除左腎點洗血、除毒、排尿，又要背佢啲結構點利用內外壓去達成上述嘅野，重要理解好多個一太多鹽或者受壓力刺激嘅荷爾蒙反應。讀呢課堅要嘥好多心力。

過咗mid-term，就係教腦神經、遺傳、基因洗牌同生物科技，中學讀過Bio嘅應該比較輕鬆，但冇讀嘅應該覺得更加辛苦同難讀。

佢每課最多成百幾頁筆記，咁多課夾埋，幾千頁筆記都有。當中有唔少係多餘，最好買本薄自抄筆記，否則你逐頁逐頁powerpoint睇或印，嘥銀時之至。呢科，提示係咁多，其餘嘅，自己參透下啦……
reviews.comment_teaching:
Mid-term之前係Wong Yung Hou教，佢英文好流利，發音好純正，講都講得好清晰。Mid-term後就係Jessica教，呢個就……算啦，畀佢？我走咗好多堂自修。

教授都係照書讀，上堂有iPRS問題，唔計分，但問簡單問題幫你清概念。當然啦，考試問題難十萬八千倍，呢科至陰功冇past paper，要靠死記爛背同多少少智慧理解，尤其荷爾蒙，唔明真係冇可能答到問題。

佢Final好衰，幾多分都唔會話你聽，直接出grade畀你，你連考幾多分先有咩grade，連佢有冇做手腳都唔知，遑論係搵佢上訴。

所以，都係嗰句，不幸要讀呢科者，努力啲啦～
reviews.comment_grading: 讀到死死下，考試好多唔識，但最後都有個B- ，好多人讀呢科都係C甚至C- 。呢科本身係殺手科，所以我都唔知自己攞到B-係教授仁慈定自己讀得算好。
reviews.comment_workload: 冇功課，一百%計考試成績，單讀已經讀死你，再添功課就係鼓勵人跳蘑菇。

reviews.author: envsppl
reviews.comment_content:
Most of the topics are DSE related.Topics are familiar to students.
But there are 2 chapters that are relatively difficult,which are nervous system and aging. These 2 chapter needs more time to study and understand as some contents are new to students.
reviews.comment_teaching: Jessica and Herrup taught so clearly during lecture lessons and their ppt are clear and easily to understand at all. They also provided lecture video for students. You can revise again after lesson.
reviews.comment_grading:
About 1 SD in both midterm and final,got B+
This course gives a good grade.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload isnt that heavy.This course only has one midterm and one final. You just need to put effort into it and memorize all the things in the powerpoint,then you will get at least B grade.

reviews.author: CWKM
reviews.comment_content: It's a more in-depth summary of HKDSE biology.It covers lots of contents with numerous slides. This course requires both understanding and memorisation.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Herrup makes the teaching atmosphere more relaxed.Professor Tang teaching tone is very boring,but straightforward. She is more systematic,teaching materials are more organised.
reviews.comment_grading: It's difficult to get a good grade unless you understand all of the lecture materials.Both final and midterm consist of MC only. But a few questions are tricky and difficult.
reviews.comment_workload: There is only 1 midterm and 1 final.

reviews.author: Tuna
reviews.comment_content:
The topic covered is really hard. Especially the part from Karl. You can barely understand the topic since week 1. I did some pre-study before class but I still could not catch up. It's about DNA.

And after few weeks teaching, the content become a bit easier. Yet, still challenging if you did not take human physiology elective in DSE. There are lots of new concepts which you haven't heard about it while the other students had studied it before.
reviews.comment_teaching:
No lecture video for the course.

Prof. Herrup's assent is good and the lecture is lively. Due to the content, I hardly catch up the meaning though I understand all his words. Sometimes he will cover the powerpoint with a really high speed and he didn't really express so well to deliver some concepts.

Jessica is better than Karl. Fair assent. You can jot down a lot of notes in the lecture and you will find it useful. She expressed better when comparing with Karl.
reviews.comment_grading:
Poor grading. Mid-term and final are the only component for the grade. And you have to study a lot of power points for it.

I got a mean for midterm and they didn't announced the final result.
Final grade --> C
reviews.comment_workload:
Only mid term and final for the course. Seems no workload but the amount of powerpoint slides are really high. Over a thousand slides for either mid term or final. And the content is really hard especially for Karl's part so you need a lot of time to understand the materials.

The required textbook is useless.

reviews.author: Spaceship
reviews.title: the only major prerequisite course for life science
reviews.comment_content: Focuses on genetics and human biology, briefly touching some other topics like biotechnology. It can help you explore whether life science is your preferred major.
reviews.comment_teaching: The teaching is about average. Prof. Herrup is organized and humorous in general but may tend to include overly specific topics with little explanation, forcing you to memorize w/o understanding the logics behind. Dr. Tang is friendly and has easy-to-follow visual aid, but her lectures tend to be dull and lacking in fluency.
reviews.comment_grading:
It is rumored that the grading is good. Many students give up this course too so the mean is quite low.
Got >2.2sd in midterm and definitely didn't do as well in the final=>A+
Work hard and A range will be within your lockdown.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is not that much, contrary to common belief. Yes there are about a thousand ppt slides to remember, but only exams count towards your grade (i.e. no assignments), and the final exam is non-cumulative. You should do fine starting to memorize everything a week before the exam. Reading the suggested textbook is also not required, if not completely useless.

I would say that the teaching of Biology is quite hard to be funny but my secondary school teacher did it great actually.
Anyway, they usually just speak what ppt have but they will answer your questios after lessons. And sometimes they will tell you whether this will provide or you need to recite in the exam. This really matter in Bio subject.
reviews.comment_grading:
Don't ever study Biology one day advance.
You will not get enough time for so many ppt and facts.

Midterm will have lots of MC and you can guess ans but final will get short questions and so you better study for a week.
reviews.comment_workload:

They will have some questions for you to practice but they are counted for marks.

reviews.author: Chaewon
reviews.comment_content:

reviews.comment_teaching: OK
reviews.comment_grading: As there are only MCQs in midterm and final exam, it's easier to get good grades as the questions are quite straight forward. It would be okay as long as you memorized the contents as the questions are mostly based on basic and detailed concepts covered during lectures.
reviews.comment_workload: No assignments to do during the course

reviews.author: Leoml
reviews.title: Bad content
reviews.comment_content:
Useless redundant content. A revision of DSE stuff with some new content that is not deep enough, basically just a bunch of new words you don’t know.
The topics are

Course Introduction and Nervous system (17)


Musculoskeletal System (19)


Heart and the Circulatory system (12)


Respiratory system (15)


Osmoregulation and Excretion (16) (skipped)


DNA structure and gene expression (25)


Patterns of gene inheritance (23)

Chromosomal basis of inheritance

Biotechnology (26)


Digestive System and Nutrition (14)

Endocrine System (20)


Lymphatic and Immune Systems (13)


Development and Aging (22)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. Miller’s lecture is good, he would try to make the lesson fun, but the lecture slides are quite messy, so it is hard to follow.
Prof. Liang’s lecture is okay, he doesn’t follow his lecture slides, it is quite hard to follow especially during 9am lessons.
Dr. Li’s lecture is the best in my opinion, she teach according to lecture slides, so it is quite easy to follow and do revision.
However, not enough depth overall.
reviews.comment_grading:
1 mid term and final, each consisting of 75 mcQs. From the predicted grade in mid term, around 20% of students get A range, which is quite good grade
Midterm: 52/75
Final: Unknown
Grade: B+
reviews.comment_workload: Very low workload, just need to revise a bit before mid term and final, which may or may not be good. I prefer some exercises to consolidate the knowledge
